revised_title: Dystrophin's Role in Calcium-Permeable Ion Channels in Cerebellar Neurons
tldr: Researchers discovered that cerebellar neurons from mdx mice, a model for Duchenne muscular dystrophy, have calcium-permeable ion channels that are open for longer durations. These channels may contribute to the pathophysiological accumulation of intracellular calcium in dystrophy, as the absence of dystrophin is associated with increased channel activity.
